19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I do not know that we could say starvation, but times did have to tighten the belt. Oatmeal porridge & some bread but this was when Blizzard's blocked the roads & money not plentiful to lay in stocks. Porridge 3 times a day no milk or sugar this was before we got to know the country & make preparations after this we got wheat at a flour mill at Saltcoats 25 miles from homeland.

1 man / 1 woman / 2 children

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I do not know what we could say about this, but I am glad how things have turned out. We had to make do with what we had. We were very thankful for the help we received from the government. After this we got work at a sawmill at Allentown 25 miles from Homestead.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

After a few years more conveniences for comfort as the wives notice fairly efficient at cooking as cooking school were in the day school curriculum in 1900 probably earlier.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). I do not remember but the way most of us did was to grow all vegetables, figs, corn, wheat, &c. Butter &c. This was until 1917 all crops grown, wheat not fit for bread, but Government was good to us & gave enough to help us over the hard times.

I also providing seed for 1908.
